We already know that \EuScript{B}=\left( \tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,-1) , \tfrac{1}{\sqrt{6}}(1,2,1) \right) =: (\Vect{u}_1,\Vect{u}_2) is an ONB of W . We can use \Vect{u}_3:=\CrssPr{ \Vect{u}_1 }{ \Vect{u}_2} or, alternatively, use the vector \Vect{x}_{\bot} found earlier and normalize it.

For each of the statements below determine if it is true or false.
The orthogonal complement of (1,1,2,1,1) in \RNr[5] has a basis of four vectors.
True!
Review the dimension formula for a subspace and its orthogonal complement.
Let V:=\span\Set{ (1,1,2,1,1) } , and let W:=V^{\bot} . Then V and W form an orthogonal splitting of \RNr[5] , and the dimension formula gives
Now \dim(V)=1 as V is spanned by the single nonzero vector (1,1,2,1,1) . Therefore, \dim(W) = 4 . – The statement in question is correct.
Any four linearly independent vectors in the orthogonal complement W of (1,1,2,1,1) in \RNr[5] form a basis of W .
True!
Review the solution of the previous problem.

We know that \dim(W)=4 . Therefore any collection of four linearly independent vectors in W
forms a basis of W
. – The statement in question is true.
Any four linearly independent vectors in \RNr[5] form a basis of the orthogonal complement W of (1,1,2,1,1) in \RNr[5] .
False!
If \Vect{a} is a basis vector of W , then \Vect{a} must lie in W . – Is the condition satisfied for each of any four linearly vectors picked randomly in \RNr[5] ?

Start with \Vect{a}:=(1,1,2,1,1) , and let \Vect{b}, \Vect{c}, \Vect{d} be any three vectors in \RNr[5] such that \Set{\Vect{a}, \Vect{b}, \Vect{c}, \Vect{d} } are linearly independent. Then this is certainly not a basis of W because \Vect{a} does not belong to W . – The statement in question is false.

True!

Let U and V be subspaces of \RNr[k] of dimension p and q , respectively. If V is contained in U^{\bot} , then q\leq k-p .
True!
How are \dim(V) and \dim(U^{\bot}) related?
We need to draw conclusions from two pieces of information:
\dim(U^{\bot}) = k - p by the dimension formula for orthogonal splittings.
q=\dim(V) \leq \dim(U^{\bot}) , as V is a subspace of U^{\bot} .
It follows that q\leq k-p . – The statement in question is true.

The orthogonal complement of the vectors \Vect{a} = (1,0,0,0) and \Vect{b}=(0,0,1,0) in \RNr[4] consists of all vectors of the form \Vect{x} = (0,a,0,b) with a,b in \RNr arbitrary.
True!
What is the dimension of the subspace of \RNr[4] that consists of the vectors \Vect{x} ?
We collect the following facts:
The vectors \Vect{a} and \Vect{b} are linearly independent. So they span a subspace U of \RNr[4] of dimension 2 .
Therefore \dim(U^{\bot}) = 4- 2 = 2 .
The vectors of the form \Vect{x} = (0,a,0,b) = a\cdot (0,1,0,0) + b\cdot (0,0,0,1) form the subspace V of \RNr[4] spanned by \StdBss{2}=(0,1,0,0) and \StdBss{4}=(0,0,0,1) . So \dim(V) = 2 .
So V is a subspace of dimension 2 of U^{\bot} .
This means that the statement in question is true.
